pros: Great university, pleasant atmosphere, being able to help students. Boston is an amazing city to live in, great location.
cons: Disorganized throughout administration - as most universities are. Disconnect between upper management and the rest of the staff.

review_title: Obtained my PhD from Northeastern University
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: there is enough freedom of doing research
cons: there are still limits on the research funding

review_title: No one at Northeastern can be bothered to do their job correctly (or at all).
pros: The campus is nice (at least from the outside). The location in Boston is good, and it is easy to get to on either the orange or green lines.
cons: Almost no one at Northeastern can be relied on to do their jobs. Secretaries, HR, the registrar all need to be harassed to get anything done. For example, my colleagues and I weren't paid one week because the secretary forgot to submit our time sheets, which is totally unacceptable.

pros: Strong students, great faculty colleagues
cons: University is poorly structured internally. Not enough collaboration and communication between different departments and campus groups. Can make for a very frustrating work experience.

pros: Great opportunity to work on-campus. Nice wage for part-time job. Great people! Interesting job task. Cannot say more cause probably not involved deep enough.
cons: I did not noticed any. Cannot say more cause probably not involved deep enough.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: The location in Boston is great. The resources available and opportunities to collaborate amidst the different departments is great.
cons: The cost of living is very high in Boston. Some of the newly formed departments are not quite organized.

pros: Could pretty much use any lab in which I needed instruments or chemicals. Cooperation was heavily encouraged between labs and students.
cons: Advisor was rarely involved/interested in my projects. Labs were cramped and not impeccably kept. Facilities were average.

review_title: Do you research before attending graduate school
pros: Choose your advisor wisely. Flexible weekly hours. Good laboratory resources and conditions.
cons: Low salary, but we are being paid to get a higher degree, it's a fair trade off.

review_title: Nice people but no real perks
pros:
-Management is very supportive and accommodating, especially to working parents.
-You almost never have to work over 40 hours a week. In fact you could probably work 30 without people noticing.
cons:
-Low pay
-No real work culture. Standard cubicles, no events, no one even ate lunch together.
-Very slow paced work
-Disorganized projects without clear goals

pros:
- Northeastern provides great resources for its employees. 
- School offers many programs and events to learn new technical skills such as Comsol or Hadoop
- Interesting and important research projects 
- Great location and fun people
cons:
- Post-doc experience highly depends on partnered professor. 
- Administration can be disorganized with official paperwork

pros: Supervisors were wonderful. A lot of the financial aid counselors are great too. Sometimes free food! Flexible hours
cons: Had to talk people through super basic steps on the computer. Some financial aid counselors seem to be a little hard to communicate with and students will consistently complain about lack of communication with 1 or 2 in particular

pros: Innovative programs and senior leadership that are always striving to be on the cutting edge of high education innovations and developments.
cons: Very challenging political climate, top down style of leadership with little regarding for input of faculty and staff working "on the ground"

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Interesting work and numerous opportunities to both adopt new analytical skills and professionally network
cons: Lack of work/balance since it's part of an academic institution. There also seems to be minor frustrations with management over perceived directions the organization should take

pros: Good opportunities to meet with professors and students at the University. Good pay as well.
cons: Not great at being organized, you aren't always sure what you should be doing. Also, students can be tough to deal with.

pros: Co-op program. Actually the Cons overweight any pros. Don't waste your time and money getting a masters degree at this place!
cons: Horrible bioinformatics masters program. Though the program is expensive, the class rooms have around 100 students(mostly from India), professors don't show up for lectures and grades are awarded based on your interaction with the professor rather than how well you do on the course work. Some students who do voluntary work at professor's labs are given better grades, basically the grading system is based on favoritism and favors

pros: The Center of Community Service at Northeastern is a wonderful place to work! Very intentional in providing their employees with opportunities for professional development. Open, friendly office. Very focused on meeting their community partners' needs as well as meaningful student development.
cons: Office location can be a little tricky to find.

pros: Tuition benefit, great work-life balance, great location
cons: No union for admin staff, low pay, toxic leadership and bureaucratic management. Heavy process-oriented for simple decisions. high turnover in many admin positions. Health benefits are worse than peer institutions. Poor career advancement opportunities for admin staff who do not have PhD, substantial work experience or does not come from a competing University.

review_title: It depends on your other offers
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Good city. Pay is fine.
cons: Some of the faculty are weak and difficult . Politics was terrible. Some students felt entitled and preferred to complaint instead of putting in more effort to learn something. School I felt was at the mercy of students and 'some' key faculty members making fundamental growth very slow.

job_title: Graduate Administrative Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Most everyone that I've worked with in a few different departments are all very nice and helpful.
cons: pay isn't very good at all, benefits were better 4 yrs ago and are continuing to get worse.

pros: Opportunities in many areas for students. In five years I've worked in financial aid, residence life, security, and alumni relations.
cons: Many positions are limited to work-study funding, so general employment/budgeted jobs are fiercely competitive.

review_title: It's a nice job to have on campus, but it gets monotonous quickly.
job_title: Library Security Proctor in Boston, MA
pros: The main pros are that there are excellent people to work with and there are good hours.
cons: The main con that I have with my position is how monotonous it is. After checking ID cards for 3 hours, I really just want to leave.

review_title: Benefits are amazing, including free tuition for master's programs
pros: free tuition; great health insurance; extra health initiatives by HR; Retirement benefits are good too.
cons: It can be difficult figuring out who to go to for certain questions since the university is very large.

review_title: I work as a tutor for undergraduate students for the course CS2800 i.e. logic and computation.
pros: I am learning quite a lot from the undergraduate course about the programming language ACL2.
cons: There are no cons for this job. I would recommend this job to quite a lot of people. What else can I say about this.

job_title: Cooperative Education Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Flexible hours, good benefits, fulfilling job.  Friendly coworkers wanting to work together.  Can pretty much make your own schedule.
cons:
Limited growth opportunity.  There was not a lot of room to advance for coordinators.  
A lot of shifting with student counselors. Makes keeping track of things a little more difficult.

review_title: A place with a modicum of bureaucracy, but not overwhelming
pros: safe, well-established, friendly faculty and staff, great vacation and benefits
cons: relatively boring, slow compared to private industry, relatively low pay compared to industry

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: This really helped me with my thesis work and also gave me exposure to some of the practical applications of my theroy.
cons: The work load is a bit high and the salary basis are low

pros: The coop is really useful for an international student with no work experience before, such as me. Computer Science is good
cons: Nothing else I think, expect that there are too many international students here.. For CS major, most students come from India, and a quarter of students from China

review_title: Great Benefits, Beautiful Campus, Tough Leadership
pros: College atmosphere is beautiful. All holidays off. Great students. Great benefits.
cons: Lots of attrition. Negativity at work. Little employee recognition. Leadership unwilling to change.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Friendly professors and coordinating staff. You embrace your leadership and communication skills and this also gives you opportunity to explore more.
cons: Just the number of students sometimes becomes concern but then we have more number of TA to handle such situations.

job_title: Teaching Assistant CCIS in Boston, MA
pros: I am a TA for the intro to computer science course, and I really can't complain. I enjoy doing office hours and interacting with students.
cons: All labs for intro to computer science are on Tuesday, so if you work in multiple labs it makes Tuesday schedule very tight.

pros:
Tuition Benefit
Relaxed Environment
Holidays/Sick days off
cons:
- Lack of leadership
- Lack of accountability
- Lack of acknowledgement for high performers
- Poor management
- Poor culture
- Lack of comradery
-Poor Pay (University tries to low ball you)
- Overall a big mess

pros:
- Flexible schedule
- Great events to participate in
- Good people to work with
- Centrally located university, well connected throughout the city.
cons: Part time opportunities are'nt much, and are pretty hard to find initially. The university should consider increasing the number of opportunities available to student, specially international students.

review_title: Research and teaching assistant from 2007 to 2014 for undergraduate students, also working in a laser lab doing research
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Gain experience, people are friendly and nice to deal with
cons: Not too challenging, have to think about future work on your own

job_title: Associate Director of Operations in Boston, MA
pros:
Great benefits (free tuition, retirement plan contribution, etc.)
Innovative and creative environment
cons:
Not always open to internal promotional opportunities
Incredibly fast-paced, which can be challenging at times when ideas are not fully thought out before implemented

review_title: I've been working as an research assistant at northeastern university for one and half year.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Nice facilities and logistics, excellent location. Good source of funding and some really nice professors.
cons: The reputation of the school seems not so well established. It's still regarded as an second tier school...

pros: Northeastern University provides plenty of opportunities for graduate students to learn and to find future jobs for a career.
cons: Northeastern University is kind of crowded at times, especially in the afternoon. The overcrowding makes it hard to find a place to work and study.

pros: Nice combo of the business world and practical academia
cons: Extraordinary changes going on in the market; Resources can be tight

pros: We have a union for adjunct faculty. We get paid for holidays and winter break. Beautiful landscaping. Nice people. Hardworking students.
cons: It is very expensive to park on the garages on campus. Food court serves unhealthy food .

pros: Great community after you learn the ins and outs. Teaching and education is a strong point. Benefits include free courses. Location is great!
cons: I had some trouble adjusting here initially. Research is not a strong point.

pros:
Excellent staff, friendly environment, structured organization, flexible routine, event management, public relations, project management, leadership. 
One can always have a great work experience under your belt
cons: Skills that you acquire may not always be relevant. Often times it gets boring & monotonous. More challenges are needed.

job_title: Sports Leadership Student in Dunkirk, MD
pros: Multiple programs offered, diverse population, 21 century education, center of Boston, easy commute
cons: Weather can be awful at times, which can make it challenging to be on time.  Since its so large hard to create community within the campus

job_title: Student Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros:
- Good Wage: as a work study, you can request any reasonable wage you want (20/hr for me)
- HR is easy to work with
- Great professors
cons: - Need to start early in you student career to do well

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: good environment and faculty, Equipped classroom and labs, proper offices for the graduate students, easy access to metro stations and downtown of Boston
cons: too many students and so expensive rent in downtown Boston, gym and specially pool facility is not good enough

pros: It's a very good  university with excellent co-op opportunity.
cons: Expensive and being middle of city makes it really difficult for the students in terms of accommodation.

pros: Opportunities to travel and work with students. Students are great!
cons: Doesn't pay well and does not provide much support for professional development (varies by department).

pros: Great environment and facilities, you determine your own schedule, have your own freedom to improvise, way to network with more people
cons: close to the min. wage, small room for improvement, sometimes you have extra work due to the nature of the position, narrow career opportunities

job_title: Engineering Lab Supervisor in Boston, MA
pros: Great Learning and good opportunities for students to work on campus
cons: It has a busy schedule at peak hours. But, we get an opportunity to help students at their last moment of submissions.

review_title: Its a great learning experience and u get to learn a lot
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Best Co-ops and internship program in the US.Its easy to get on campus jobs and everything can be balanced easily
cons: Difficult if u r in IE or EM

review_title: As a student technician, I was responsible for greeting and helping customers at the front desk, as well as tech issues.
job_title: IT Help Desk in Boston, MA
pros: I love the flexibility of customer service and being an actual IT technician and working on customers' machines directly.
cons: Management a bit rusty, slow.

pros: All you have to do is sit around at the desk during office hours, sometimes help residents with lockouts. Dorm fee for the semester is taken care off.
cons: You get lockout calls sometimes in the middle of the night.

pros: Great benefits, campus, pay, professional colleagues, nice office space, great events staff and catering.
cons: If you work in one of the colleges, you are sharing bathroom space with undergrads. Need I say more?

job_title: Part Time Faculty in Boston, MA
pros: Supportive environment, great people, extremely organized!
cons: No parking readily available in the Boston Campus - must take public transportation but the commuter rail has a stop right in the middle of the campus, so no issues!

review_title: Good research opportunities, pay is much less than the commercial sector
pros: Academic freedom, everybody is very nice, great culture
cons: Terrible health insurance. I had to pay a significant amount of my salary for the basic plan. 403(k) is only available after 2 years of service.

pros:
Appealing campus and environment. 
Diversified culture and can make new friends.
Excellent on-campus jobs, assistantships and co-op/internships.
A way to experience professional world.
Involvement with the community and service.
cons: Needs to be patient and wait for the right time to grab the opportunity.

pros: Not bad for a grad student, good environment, decent hours, lots of support. Decent living situation. I liked the bosses.
cons: Bad department that was often unorganized. Lots of students that made facilities an issue. Overcrowded, underfunded, overall could be improved

pros:
Everyone wants you to do well and exceed in both your personal and professional goals! 
Benefits are great, ability to go back to school. 
Opportunity for growth.
cons: Summer's can be quiet and not as busy without as many students on campus.

job_title: Help Desk Technician in Boston, MA
pros: Deep discount on up to 9 credits per semester
cons: Horrible supervisors. The don't care about those who work for them.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Good learning experience of working with faculty and administration and a good impact on the resume.
cons: The number of hours is very less and it is sufficient to cover your grocery and food bills but won't cover our whole month's expenses.

review_title: Care more about bottom line than students and siloed
job_title: Director of Advising in Boston, MA
pros: Students and available resources to run programming
cons: Administration cares more about the bottom line than students; they admit more students can they can support; departments and units are very siloed; unhealthy competition; lack of communication

pros:
Great working environment, well organized, clean. I worked with a great team of super-smart mates. 
Living in Boston, despite the wheather, is a plus to this position.
cons: I didn't find really any problem there so...I have nothing to write here...

pros: Flexible hours, amazing co workers, very fun environment, not too difficult.
cons: there aren't many cons because this job is very fun the only thing is that when you're on shift there are strict protocols and guidelines you must follow.

review_title: The research assistant position is exciting and a great opportunity to have while pursuing a graduate de
job_title: Research Assistant (Graduate Student) in Boston, MA
pros: Good location, friendly and helpful professors, supportive research environment, chances for professional growth.
cons: Administrative aspects can move slowly.

pros: I have been a PhD student in Northeastern. The school is expanding, we have a lot new areas to have research on.
cons: Because it is expanding, everyone is really busy and the management isn't so well

pros: Faculty, staff and students are pretty top notch. I was fortunate to work frequently with students and found them totally engaged and eager to learn and improve.
cons: A need for better overall strategy towards professional development.

pros: You can do your homework while you work, very flexible work schedules, people are friendly.
cons: Pretty mundane work if you are unlucky enough to actually be there when they deliver mail. The weighing and sorting is no fun.

pros:
Faculty are brilliant and very conversational for the most part.  
Peers are motivated and don't fit the college stereotype of whiny and entitled.  
Co-op is fantastic.
cons: Can't go through the Fens on a night jog.

pros: Earned my MBA for free! Relaxed environment, flexible schedule, amazing benefits, tons of paid time off and sick days, nice campus, lots of fun events, own office with a door.
cons: Bureaucratic processes, lots of red tape, commuting into Boston.

review_title: describe Northeastern Campus in a sentence:
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Nice campus and great available team work researches are going on here at Northeastern.
cons: Lack of organized and expert labs comparing with other top schools in the city.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: It has a lot of opportunities to find a job in Boston area and Northeastern University is #1 in Co-op program which is also a good thing for a job.
cons: Living expense is the problem in Boston area.

job_title: Professor of the Practice in Boston, MA
pros: Dynamic and inspiring environment, engaged students
cons: International students' language capabilities sometimes too low; no cross-pollination between part-timers encouraged which strongly reduces their ability to do research.

pros: Friendly work environment, friendly staff, flexible work hours and decent pay, low pressure work
cons: 6 month contract must be signed, which could be problem if looking for a coop.

job_title: Associate Research Scientist in Boston, MA
pros: low pressure, good resources, awesome students, great growth in the past 10 years
cons: no clear career progression, support staff overwhelmed, building not designed for collaboration

pros: It has the best system of working within its own coding system for shelfing & therefore train you towards docket system.
cons: There is no con for the job but its not relevant to my study field

review_title: Great place to work while you're earning your degree
pros: Tuition reimbursement is top notch; it's easy to get your degree here while working.
cons: Some offices are farther away from campus, making it challenging to feel like a part of the community.

pros: Benefits are excellent. Lots of structural improvements happening on campus
cons: Pay is lower than some local universities. Takes forever to get anything done. Very very political

pros:
I've been working for Northeastern on and off for over a decade. Overall it is a very good place of work.
* Good benefits
* Friendly people
* Good atmosphere
cons:
A bit disorganized
Geared toward undergraduate students
Not many jobs

review_title: My position as the Lead Athletic Facilities Coordinator for twenty years at Northeastern University, was very rewarding.
job_title: Athletic Facilities Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Very satisfying and rewarding work, leading a group of men every day and organizing work schedules.
cons: I cannot think of any cons.

job_title: Certified Personal Trainer in Boston, MA
pros: this is where I work while at school.  As an international student I have to work on campus
cons: Its a great environment for new trainers, however I have been a trainer for 5 plus years

pros:
Passionate advising staff and student workers
University leadership supports global initiatives
Intelligent and driven student body
cons:
Lack of organization and data driven decision making
Students' financial health, safety on programs,  and academic progress suffer as a result of poor departmental management

review_title: Hassle free and somewhat creative jon
pros: Working for a consulting department it was quite hassle free work with changes of applying creativity and problem solving skills to provide recommendations.
cons: Being an non profit organization do not except higher pay rates.

review_title: Job as an IM sports official
pros: This the best job one could possibly ask for . Recreation and work both go hand in hand
cons: The job has absolutely no cons and I look forward to work each day

pros: All the courses that I have attended so far is really good. Professors know what they are teaching and take interests in binding students to the concepts been taught in class.
cons: No Cons experienced so far

pros: There are many great people to work with
cons: Sometimes work is under compensated, or university moves so fast on different initiatives that your work becomes irrelevant or has to go unfinished for a new project

review_title: Northeastern University is a dynamic research institution with an international research and teaching reputation.
pros: Dynamic environment that embraces entrepreneurial thinking and change.
cons: The institution has changed so fast, that some employees haven't adapted working in an entirely different environment.

pros: Great people to work with, up and coming university with a lot of new research activity
cons: Infrastructure is not evolving with increasing enrollment and grand funding

pros: Amazing Payrates, casual atmosphere with little stress on workdays.
cons: Walking all the way to the RSO office on bitter cold days, for swiping out after the shift.

review_title: Great for Personal and Career Growth
pros: The pay may be low, but there are fabulous benefits, including free tuition (if you get in). I like it here a lot!
cons: Low pay, not challenging

pros: People are in general very pleasant. Professors I worked with are knowledgeable and care about their students' learning.
cons: Some confusion sometimes about pay, but generally resolved with time.

review_title: Good place to learn and grow..learnt a lot and managers were very nurturing in terms of parting their knowledge
pros: Learnt a lot and took some night classes as well.
cons: can't think of anything except not a great lunch place to go.

pros: Lots of time off, great location of campus, tuition reimbursement, awesome coworkers.
cons: Higher Education is a low paying industry (for staff). There are other amazing benefits, but pay is on the lower side.

review_title: Extremely professional, amazing people to work with
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Its an academic institution. You are always learning
cons: Not industry level environment. Missing out on a lot of happening things.

review_title: Good launching pad for another career
job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Boston, MA
pros: Good benefits i.e. time off and free classes. Friendly work culture
cons: Limited direct growth opportunities. seems you need to transfer internally or leave the university for significant promotion. Good launching pad

Smart co-workers

pros: Tuition waiver benefit, convenient location easily accessible by T

pros: Highly motivated students. Great colleagues. Commitment by administration to strategic shifts to remain ahead of the changing higher education landscape. Stimulating environment to work in!
cons: Budget constraints can impede changes that are trying to be made.

pros: They take care very well of employees.
cons: Rules and regulations are followed strictly.

review_title: Great place to work, but must be able to adapt easily.
pros: Benefits are great, people are wonderful, always pushing for something new.
cons: No real direction frorm leadership. Always looking for new shiny thing rather than focusing on fundamentals.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Boston, MA
pros: collaborative, innovative researchers. Supportive department and good sense of community
cons: High turn-over of upper admin meant that financial paperwork could get lost, or take a long time to process. Accounting occasionally forgot to pay certain labs.

review_title: It was nice working with the Northeastern University..They give you chance to growup in the company.
pros: The work shifts helps the students to work on-campus according to the class schedules

review_title: Northeastern University lab assistant job is good

Moving up quickly in the rankings

pros: It is in a very good location, Very diverse environment, Good Management, Great teachers

pros: Flexible, Good Pay, Freindly student Atmosphere, and Comfortable, convinient work hours.

review_title: Northeastern is great to work for

pros: Outstanding research environment. Crazy amount of resources in terms of high profile faculty and budget for research. Going to top conferences in my field (Electrical Engineering).

pros: Great school with lots of research opportunities to get experience.
